summary: the origin of the exacerbated cytokine response is unclear. the aim of the present study was to evaluate the relationship between host cytokine responses and viral levels. a number of studies report increased and persistent levels of cytokines and chemokines paralleling severe disease. a exacerbated cytokine response can contribute to immune-mediated tissue damage during viral infections. the cause of the observed hypercytokinemia in 2009 pandemic influenza is unclear. a standard survey was employed to collect clinical data, including history and physical examination, oximetric measurement, haematological, biochemical, radiological and microbiological investigation in all participants centers. informed consent was obtained directly from each patient or their legal representative and also from healthy controls before enrolment. cRNA control was manufactured from PCR product cloned into plasmid (pGEM-T Easy Vector System, Promega) this plasmid contained a T7 RNA polymerase promoter upstream of the insert to drive transcription by this enzyme. the plasmid was linearized with a restriction enzyme downstream of the insert. RNA was purified using MEGAclear Kit (Ambion) inactivated pandemic influenza A/California/07/2009 antigens were measured in patients and controls by using the multiplex Bio-Rad 27-plex assay. the system allows for quantitative measurement of 27 different chemokines, cytokines, growth factors and immune mediators while consuming a small amount of biological material. ICUs with primary viral pneumonia during acute phase of influenza virus illness were recruited from November 1st to December 31st 2009. only those patients with confirmed H1N1 infection by real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) were included in the study. cRNA control was manufactured from PCR product cloned into plasmid. this plasmid contained a T7 RNA polymerase promoter downstream of the insert. RNA was purified using MEGAclear kit (Ambion) 98.3% efficiency was directly detected in the initial positive pharyngeal swab by RT-PCR and sequencing of a 1296-bp fragment of the neuraminidase gene for the presence of the mutation H274Y. standard respiratory and blood cultures were performed to assess the presence of bacterial and fungal infection.
